channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Confronting Racism in Berlin, One Offensive T-Shirt at a Time
item.media:description: Isaiah Lopaz, an American living in Berlin, has found a creative way to address instances of racism he has encountered there: put the offending comments on T-shirts.
item.description: Isaiah Lopaz, a black, college-educated artist and writer living in Berlin, was frequently assumed to be a drug dealer. Then he had an idea for how to respond.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: ‘American Democracy Is Bigger Than Any One Person,’ Obama Says
item.media:description: President Obama toured the Acropolis of Athens on Wednesday for the first time.
item.description: Visiting Greece on his final international tour as president, Mr. Obama again discussed Donald J. Trump’s election victory.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Reykjavik Journal: Secret to Iceland’s Tourism Boom? A Financial Crash and a Volcanic Eruption
item.media:description: Diddi Bardarson, who predicts another financial collapse in Iceland, is not relying on tourism. Instead, he breeds hundreds of Icelandic horses on a ranch in Hella, a town southeast of Reykjavik. Iceland exports nearly 4,000 horses a year, and a fine stallion can fetch more than $2 million.
item.media:credit: Bara Kristinsdottir for The New York Times
item.description: Two catastrophes — a 2008 crash that made the country cheap for visitors and a 2010 blast that put it on the map — transformed the island into a top destination.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: A Call to Prayer, or Noise Pollution? Israel Targets Mosque Loudspeakers
item.media:description: Al-Omeri mosque in Lod, Israel, a city of Arabs and Jews. A proposal backed by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu would authorize the government to ban the use of loudspeakers by mosques and other houses of worship across the country.
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.description: In response to noise complaints, a proposal backed by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu would ban the use of loudspeakers by mosques summoning the faithful.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Airstrikes on Aleppo Resume as Russia Begins New Offensive in Syria
item.description: An end to the relative calm in rebel-held areas of the city came a day after President Vladimir V. Putin and President-elect Donald J. Trump agreed to bolster cooperation.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and IVAN NECHEPURENKO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Yemeni Bankers Get in Trouble Over a Customer, Al Qaeda
item.media:description: A branch of Al Omgy Brothers Money Exchange, in Sana, Yemen. The United States designated the company as having provided support to Al Qaeda.
item.description: A Yemeni money exchange was lauded for providing a crucial service even as terrorists reigned. But its dealings with Al Qaeda have put it in the cross hairs of the United States.
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI and BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula

item.title: Korean Mother Awaits a Son’s Deportation to Confess Her ‘Unforgivable Sin’
item.media:description: Kwon Pil-ju, the biological mother of Adam Crapser, at home in Yeongju, South Korea.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: Kwon Pil-ju will soon be reunited with the son she gave up for adoption when he was a baby, confronting a shame she’s felt for 40 years.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Indonesia Says Jakarta’s Christian Governor Is Suspected of Blasphemy
item.media:description: Gov. Basuki Tjahaja Purnama of Jakarta campaigning for re-election on Tuesday in the city, Indonesia’s capital.
item.description: The country was thrown into turmoil after Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, the capital’s governor, was named a suspect in an inquiry over comments he made about the Quran.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: ‘We Have a Fake Election’: China Disrupts Local Campaigns
item.media:description: Casting a ballot in Beijing on Tuesday. Every five years, the government encourages people to vote in local elections, which are democratic in name only.
item.description: Tuesday was Election Day in Beijing, but despite urging voters to “treasure democratic rights,” the government bullied and detained activists and candidates.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Business or Politics? What Trump Means for Cuba
item.media:description: A home in Havana last week. During his presidential campaign, Donald J. Trump vowed to roll back policy initiatives that expanded business and travel in Cuba.
item.description: Mr. Trump has threatened to roll back President Obama’s sweeping détente, but some analysts say the president-elect’s instincts as a real estate mogul and hotel developer would ultimately prevail.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Canadian Brewery Cuts a Retiree Perk: Free Beer for Life
item.media:description: The retail store beside the Labatt brewery in Toronto in 2005, the year the brewery was closed.
item.description: Labatt, citing an effort to cut costs, is ending a policy that allowed its retired workers to receive free beer for life.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Abroad in America: A Reporter Retraces His Steps Through Trump Country
item.media:description: Williamson, W.Va., a decimated coal town, as Hillary Clinton visited in May. During his presidential campaign, Donald J. Trump promised to “bring back coal.”
item.media:credit: Ty Wright for The New York Times
item.description: Since July, Declan Walsh has been applying the perspective of a New York Times foreign correspondent to the U.S. election. This is his final report.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: What in the World: In China, One Music Website Is Always No. 1
item.media:description: Douban.com is essential to China’s growing music scene. The site attracts more than 40 percent of Chinese internet users every month.
item.description: The Chinese market is dominated by Douban, which exposes users to thousands of bands around the world and is essential to China’s own music scene.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL GRIFFITHS

item.title: Syrian President Calls Donald Trump a ‘Natural Ally’ in Fight Against Terrorism
item.media:description: Destroyed buildings in the Syrian village of Kfar Jales, near Idlib, on Wednesday, following air strikes by Syrian and Russian warplanes.
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Bashar al-Assad also predicted that “opposing forces” in the U.S. government and criticism from the news media could affect Mr. Trump’s actions.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: India Bans Organization Run by Controversial Televangelist Preacher
item.media:description: Zakir Naik, a popular televangelist preacher, spoke by videoconference in July. In his speeches, Dr. Naik has harshly criticized the United States.
item.description: The organization, the Islamic Research Foundation, was banned after accusations that the preacher, Zakir Naik, promoted terrorism through his speeches.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Sinosphere: Finding a Rich Vein of Humor in China’s Past
item.description: Christopher Rea, a literary historian, discusses the flowering of comedy, farce and satire in early 20th-century China, and the parallels to be found today.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: House Votes to Extend Iran Sanctions in Bid to Ensure Nuclear Compliance
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran in September. Trying to reassure his cabinet ministers after Donald J. Trump’s election, Mr. Rouhani said that Iran’s nuclear agreement “cannot be overturned by one government’s decision.”
item.description: The legislation, which would continue sanctions for 10 years, needs Senate approval and President Obama’s signature before the end of the year.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: At U.N. Meeting, Diplomats Worry Trump Could Cripple Climate Pact
item.media:description: Morrocan honor guards waited for the arrival of world leaders at the opening of the climate change summit conference at the Royal Palace in Marrakesh, Morocco, on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Some diplomats at the global warming summit meeting called for retaliation to compel American compliance with the Paris accord approved a year ago.
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: In Czech Republic, Some Hope a Trump Could Bring Star Power
item.media:description: Ivana and Donald J. Trump in 1989.
item.description: Ivana Trump, the president-elect’s first wife, says she wants to be ambassador to the Czech Republic, a prospect that excites many in her homeland.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and HANA de GOEIJ

item.title: Images of a Supermoon Spectacle
item.description: Photographs from around the world captured the biggest and brightest full moon in nearly 70 years on Sunday and Monday nights.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: John Kerry’s Antarctica Visit Highlights a Continent, and Climate Policies, Under Threat
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry on a frozen section of the Ross Sea near Scott Base, Antarctica, on Saturday. Mr. Kerry has made conservation efforts a central part of American diplomacy, but Donald J. Trump’s administration may reverse course.
item.description: Mr. Kerry’s visit capped nearly four years of diplomatic focus on conservation issues. Now the prospect looms that Donald J. Trump will rip up those efforts.
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN GILLIS

item.title: Afghanistan Fires 7 From Cabinet in Intensifying Political Crisis
item.media:description: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan in Kabul in June. He has challenged Parliament’s decision to dismiss several cabinet ministers.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: The suddenly empty positions, adding to two others because of resignations, will further bog down the work of a struggling government.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Tehran Journal: As a Noxious Smog Descends, Tehran Tries to Ignore It
item.media:description: A blanket of smog covered Tehran on Monday. Every year, heavy pollution gets trapped by the Alborz Mountains.
item.description: A winter-long miasma of smoke and dust is the new normal in Tehran and many other cities, so much so that fatalistic Iranians simply pretend that the sky is blue and the air is clean.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Canada Takes Steps to Address Discriminatory Policies Against Gays
item.media:description: Justin Trudeau became the first Canadian prime minister to march in the Pride Festival parade in July. His government has taken steps to combat a history of discrimination against sexual minorities.
item.description: A new measure will make the age of consent 16 for anal sex, and a government appointee will look into cases of federal discrimination against gay and transgender people.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Visiting Europe, Obama Warns Against Rise of ‘Crude Sort of Nationalism’
item.description: President Obama, apparently referring to Donald J. Trump’s decision to appoint a hard-right nationalist to a top post, spoke in Greece during his final overseas trip as president.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Leaked ‘Brexit’ Memo Says U.K. Is Unsure How to Proceed
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain has offered few details about what she favors in the country’s break from the European Union.
item.description: A report in the British media whose origins were not revealed said 30,000 additional civil servants would be needed to negotiate departure from the E.U.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Court in Egypt Overturns Mohamed Morsi’s Death Sentence
item.media:description: Mohamed Morsi, the ousted Egyptian president, during his trial in Cairo in June.
item.description: Mr. Morsi, a leader of the Muslim Brotherhood and former president, is likely to remain in prison indefinitely. Executing him could unsettle the country.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Jackie Chan: The Fists, the Fury, the Oscar
item.media:description: Jackie Chan in a scene from “Supercop.”
item.description: The legend in martial arts cinema has more than 200 credits as an actor, director, producer and writer. And, now, he has an Honorary Academy Award.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH

item.title: A Chinese Farmer’s Execution Shows the Pitfalls of Rapid Urbanization
item.media:description: A construction site on the outskirts of Shijiazhuang in Hebei Province last month.
item.description: The demolition of the farmer’s home to allow property development led to a village official’s death, but the case drew sympathy from the public and lawyers.
item.dc:creator: OWEN GUO

item.title: Germany Bans ‘True Religion’ Muslim Group and Raids Mosques
item.media:description: The police raided a mosque in Hamburg, Germany, on Tuesday. Officers searched 190 premises in more than half of the country’s 16 states.
item.description: The organization is known for distributing German-language copies of the Quran. Officials say 140 of its recruits have traveled to fight in Syria or Iraq.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Sinosphere: Xi Jinping Wants to Be ‘Comrade.’ For Gay Chinese, That Means Something Else.
item.media:description: Members of the Chinese Communist Party’s Politburo Standing Committee, including President Xi Jinping, center, at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing in July. The party is asking its members to call one another “comrade.’'
item.description: Among gay men in China, “comrade” is most often used as a term of affection and solidarity.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Hong Kong Court Bars 2 Pro-Independence Politicians From Office
item.media:description: Yau Wai-ching, one of the two pro-independence politicians affected by the decision, outside the High Court in Hong Kong on Tuesday.
item.description: The ruling effectively ended a case in which Beijing had taken extraordinary steps to influence local politics in the semiautonomous city.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: In a Late-Night Move, Russia Arrests a Top Economic Official in a Bribery Case
item.media:description: The economy minister of Russia, Alexei Ulyukayev, in Moscow on Nov. 1. He is the highest-level official arrested in Russia since a failed coup in 1991.
item.description: Alexei Ulyukayev, the minister of economic development, was detained on charges of soliciting $2 million as a thank-you for endorsing an oil deal.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why Ukraine Is Losing the War on Corruption
item.media:description: The former Georgian president Mikheil Saakashvili at a news conference in Kiev this month.
item.description: I know from Georgia the challenges of reforming a post-Soviet state, but the leadership in Kiev is failing to rein in its kleptocrats.
item.dc:creator: MIKHEIL SAAKASHVILI

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Turkey’s Populists See an Unlikely Ally
item.media:description: Outside the mausoleum of the founder of modern Turkey, Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, on the 78th anniversary of his death this month.
item.description: Donald Trump’s Islamophobia isn’t enough to turn off President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his supporters.
item.dc:creator: MUSTAFA AKYOL
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Editorial: New Presidents Who Tilt Toward Russia
item.description: Elections in Bulgaria and Moldova offer more evidence of growing disenchantment in Eastern Europe with Western liberal attitudes.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
